Sheltered by the [[Western Ghats]] on the east and surrounded by the [[Arabian Sea]] on the west, Dakshina Kannada receives abundant rainfall during the [[monsoon]].{{cite web| url = http://nriforumkarnataka.org/districts-profile/Dakshina%20Kannada%20District%20Profile_29-05-2012_final.pdf | title = Dakshina Kannada - the afforest conurbation | accessdate =23 May 2015 | publisher = Ernst & Young |date=June 2012}}{{cite web| url = http://dcmsme.gov.in/dips/Dakshina%20Kannada%20%20DIst-final.pdf | title = Brief Industrial Profile of Dakshina Kannada District | accessdate =31 January 2015 | publisher = Government of India - Ministry of MSME}} It is bordered by [[Udupi District]] to the north, [[Chikkamagaluru district]] to the northeast, [[Hassan District]] to the east, [[Kodagu]] to the southeast, and [[Kasaragod District]] in [[Kerala]] to the south.{{cite web| url = http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in:8080/jspui/bitstream/10603/25483/10/10_chapter_03.pdf | title = Chapter 3 - Profile of the study Area - Coastal Karnataka | accessdate =23 May 2015 | publisher = Shodhganga}} [[Mangalore|Mangalore City]] is the district headquarters of Dakshina Kannada.{{cite web| url = http://pppinindia.com/pdf/karnataka/District%20Profiles/Dakshin%20Kannada.pdf | title = Dakshina Kannada District Profile | accessdate =22 February 2015 | publisher = Government of Karnataka}}
The district has 2 agroclimatic divisions namely # [[Coastal plain|Coastal region]] - consists of [[Mangalore taluk|Mangalore]] and [[Bantwal taluk|Bantwal]] taluks # [[Western Ghats|Malnad region]] - consists of [[Puttur taluk|Puttur]], [[Belthangady taluk|Belthangady]] and [[Sullia taluk|Sullia]] taluks.{{cite web| url =http://agricoop.nic.in/Agriculture%20contingency%20Plan/KTK/KAR13-DAKSHINA%20KANNADA%2031.03.2011.pdf | title = Agriculture Contingency Plan for District: DAKSHINA KANNADA| accessdate = 31 January 2015| publisher=Agricoop}}
The district has 2 revenue subdivisions - [[Mangalore]] (consists of [[Mangalore]], [[Bantwal]], [[Moodabidri]], [[Mulki, India|Mulki]] and [[Vitla]]) and [[Puttur, Karnataka|Puttur]] (consists of [[Puttur, Karnataka|Puttur]], [[Belthangady]], [[Sullia]] and [[Kadaba]]).{{cite web| url =https://nrhm-mis.nic.in/DLHS4/State%20and%20District%20Factsheets/Karnataka/District%20Factsheets/Dakshina%20Kannada.pdf | title = District Fact Sheet - Dakshina Kannada (2012 - 2013)| accessdate = 23 July 2016| publisher=International Institue for Population Sciences}} [[File:Dk-dist-map.png|300px|border|right|Map showing the taluks of Dakshina Kannada District]] The district is divided into five [[taluka]]s namely [[Mangalore]], [[Bantwal]], [[Puttur, Karnataka|Puttur]], [[Sullia]], and [[Belthangady]].{{cite web| url = http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/karnataka/tehsil/dakshin-kannada.html | title = Dakshina Kannada Tehsil Map | accessdate =31 January 2015 | publisher = Maps Of India}} It used to include 4 northern talukas, [[Udupi]], [[Kundapur]], [[Karkala]] and [[Byndoor]], but these were separated in August 1997 to form [[Udupi district]].{{cite web |url=http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in:8080/jspui/bitstream/10603/11142/13/13_chapter%203.pdf |title=Chapter III - Profile of Karnataka state |accessdate=25 May 2015 |publisher=Shodhganga }} Dakshina Kannada, [[Udupi district|Udupi]] and [[Kasaragod district|Kasaragod]] are often called [[Tulu Nadu]], as [[Tulu language|Tulu]] is the majority language in the region.{{cite web| url = http://journal.oraltradition.org/files/articles/11i/15_rai.pdf | title = Epics in the Oral Genre System of Tulunadu | accessdate =23 May 2015 |author=B A Viveka Rai | publisher = Oral Tradition}} The [[Alupas]] ruled this region between the 8th and 14th century CE as a feudatory of all the major [[Kannada]] empires of those times and it is for this reason that the [[Tulu language|Tulu]] speaking districts are a part of [[Karnataka]].{{cite book|last=Bhat|first=N. Shyam|title=South Kanara, 1799–1860: a study in colonial administration and regional response|publisher=Mittal Publications|year=1998|isbn=978-81-7099-586-9}} Important places in Dakshina Kannada include [[Mangalore]], [[Bantwal]], [[Vittal]], [[Puttur, Karnataka|Puttur]], [[Sullia]], [[Surathkal]], [[Moodabidri]], [[Uppinangadi|Uppinangady]], [[Venur]], [[Mulki, India|Mulki]], [[Dharmasthala]], [[Ujire]], [[Belthangady]] and [[Subramanya, Karnataka|Subramanya]].{{cite web |url=https://www.karnataka.gov.in/gazetteer/HandbookKarnataka2010/Chapter%20IX%20Administration.pdf |title=A Handbook of Karnataka - Chapter IX - Administration |accessdate=25 May 2015 |publisher=Government of Karnataka}} The district is known for pristine beaches, red clay roof tiles ([[Mangalore tiles]]), cashew nut and its products, banking, education, healthcare and exotic cuisine.{{cite web |url=http://www.new1.dli.ernet.in/data1/upload/insa/INSA_1/20005af6_260.pdf |title=A brief history of scientific technology, research and educational progress of South Kanara |accessdate=20 May 2015 |publisher=Indian Journal of History of Science |author=M N Madhyastha |author2=M Abdul Rahman |author3=K M Kaveriappa}} According to 2011 Indian Census, the district ranks second in per capita income,{{cite web |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/bengaluru/Karnataka-Slips-to-Sixth-Spot-in-Per-Capita-Income/2016/03/21/article3338164.ece |title=Karnataka slips to 6th spot in Per Capita Income |accessdate=23 July 2016 |author=The New Indian Express }} second in HDI,{{cite web |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/karnataka/HDI-Bengaluru-Urban-DK-Udupi-Top-List/2015/10/20/article3089112.ece |title=HDI: Bengaluru Urban, DK, Udupi top list |accessdate=23 July 2016 |author=The New Indian Express }} first in literacy {{cite web |url=http://www.daijiworld.com/news/news_disp.asp?n_id=174610 |title=It’s official: State’s population is 6.10 cr, Dakshina Kannada most literate district |accessdate=23 July 2016 |author=Daijiworld }} and third in sex ratio among all districts in [[Karnataka]].{{cite web |url=http://www.daijiworld.com/news/news_disp.asp?n_id=98618 |title=Bangalore has Lowest Sex Ratio, DK Highest Literacy Rate in State |accessdate=23 July 2016 |author=Daijiworld }} == History == Before 1860, Dakshina Kannada was part of a district called [[Kanara]], which was under a single administration in the [[Madras Presidency]].{{cite web |url=https://indianhistorybooks.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/inscriptions-of-madras-presidency-vol-2.pdf |title=Inscriptions of the Madras Presidency |accessdate=25 May 2015 |author=V Rangacharya }} In 1860, the British split the area into South Kanara and North Kanara, the former being retained in the Madras Presidency, while the latter was made a part of [[Bombay Province]] in 1862.{{cite web |url=http://dsal.uchicago.edu/reference/gazetteer/pager.html?objectid=DS405.1.I34_V14_363.gif |title= Imperial Gazetteer of India, South Kanara|accessdate= 4 September 2009 |publisher=dsal.uchicago.edu}} [[Kundapur Taluk|Kundapur taluk]] was earlier included in North Kanara, but was re-included in South Kanara later.{{cite web |url=http://dspace.wbpublibnet.gov.in:8080/jspui/bitstream/10689/11125/3/Chapter%201_1%20-%2045p.pdf |title=Imperial Gazetteer of India - Volume XI |accessdate=20 May 2015 |publisher=Imperial Gazetteer of India }} During the Reorganisation of States in 1956, [[Kasaragod district|Kasaragod]] was split and transferred to the newly created [[Kerala]] state and Dakshina Kannada was transferred to [[Mysore State|Mysore state]] (present day [[Karnataka]]).{{cite web |url=http://www.commonlii.org/in/legis/num_act/sra1956250/ |title=States Reorganization Act 1956 |accessdate=1 July 2008 |publisher=Commonwealth Legal Information Institute |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080516123014/http://www.commonlii.org/in/legis/num_act/sra1956250/ |archivedate=16 May 2008}} [[South Canara]] was a district under the British empire which included the present Dakshina Kannada, Udupi, Kasaragod districts and [[Aminidivi]] islands.{{cite web |url=https://indianhistorybooks.files.wordpress.com/2013/05/inscriptions-of-madras-presidency-vol-2.pdf |title=Inscriptions of the Madras Presidency |accessdate=25 May 2015 |author=V Rangacharya }}{{cite web |url=http://lakshadweep.nic.in/documents/Districtmapnew.pdf |title=Template for district gazetteer - Lakshadweep |accessdate=25 May 2015 |publisher=National Informatics Centre, Lakshadweep }} [[Kanara|Canara]] district was bifurcated in 1859 to form North Canara and South Canara.{{cite web |url=http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in:8080/jspui/bitstream/10603/30037/13/13_chapter%206.pdf |title=The Basel Mission in South Canara |accessdate=20 May 2015 |author=Fedrick Sunil Kumar N I |publisher=Department of History, University of Calicut, 2006 }} Dakshina Kannada became a district of [[Mysore State]] in 1956 which later was renamed [[Karnataka]] in 1973. [[Kasaragod district|Kasaragod]] became a district of Kerala during the Re-organization of States and Aminidivi islands later became a part of [[Lakshadweep]].{{cite web |url=http://www.cds.ac.in/krpcds/publication/downloads/69.pdf |title=Forest-Agriculture Linkage and its Implications on Forest Management: A study of Delampady panchayat, Kasaragod district, Kerala |accessdate=20 May 2015 |author=Amruth M |publisher=Kerala Research Programme on Local Level Development Centre for Development Studies }} The Udupi district was formed from the northern taluks of Dakshina Kannada in 1997.Patsy Lozupone, Bruce M. Beehler, Sidney Dillon Ripley.(2004).[https://books.google.com/books?client=safari&cd=1&num=100&id=-jdHAAAAYAAJ&dq=South+Canara+coordinates&q=South+Kanara+ ''Ornithological gazetteer of the Indian subcontinent'', p. 82].Center for Applied Biodiversity Science, Conservation International. ISBN 1-881173-85-2. Later, the [[Karnataka]] Government, for the purpose of administration, split the greater Dakshina Kannada district into Udupi and present day Dakshina Kannada districts on 15 August 1997.{{cite web |url=http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in:8080/jspui/bitstream/10603/11142/13/13_chapter%203.pdf |title=Chapter III - Profile of Karnataka state |accessdate=25 May 2015 |publisher=Shodhganga }} Three taluks of the former district namely [[Udupi taluk|Udupi]], [[Karkala taluk|Karkala]] and [[Kundapura taluk|Kundapura]] formed the new [[Udupi district]].{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=8170995868 |title= South Kanara, 1799-1860: A Study in Colonial Administration and Regional Response|accessdate= 31 January 2015 |publisher=N. Shyam Bhat}} ==Demographics== {{bar box |title=Religions in Dakshina Kannada |titlebar=#Fcd116 |left1=Religion |right1=Percent |float=right |bars= {{bar percent|[[Hindus]]|orange|67.18}} {{bar percent|[[Muslims]]|green|24.02}} {{bar percent|[[Christians]]|blue|8.20}} {{bar percent|Others|brown|0.6}} |caption=
'''source:''' http://www.census2011.co.in/data/religion/district/252-dakshina-kannada.html }} According to the [[2011 census of India|2011 census]] Dakshina Kannada has a [[Demographics of India|population]] of 2,089,649,{{cite web | url = http://www.census2011.co.in/census/district/252-dakshina-kannada.html | title = District Census 2011 | accessdate = 2011-09-30 | year = 2011 | publisher = Census2011.co.in}} roughly equal to the nation of [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]{{cite web | author = US Directorate of Intelligence | title = Country Comparison - Population | url = https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2119rank.html | accessdate = 2011-10-01}} or the US state of [[New Mexico]].{{cite web|url=http://2010.census.gov/2010census/data/apportionment-pop-text.php |title=2010 Resident Population Data |publisher=U. S. Census Bureau |accessdate=2011-09-30 |quote=New Mexico - 2,059,179 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019160532/http://2010.census.gov/2010census/data/apportionment-pop-text.php |archivedate=19 October 2013 }} This gives it a ranking of 220th in India (out of a total of [[Districts of India|640]]). The district has a population density of {{convert|457|PD/sqkm|PD/sqmi}}.{{cite web| url = http://www.census2011.co.in/census/district/252-dakshina-kannada.html | title = Dakshina Kannada District : Census 2011 data | accessdate =31 January 2015| publisher = Census 2011}} Its [[Family planning in India|population growth rate]] over the decade 2001-2011 was 9.8%. Dakshina Kannada has a [[sex ratio]] of 1018 [[Women in India|females]] for every 1000 males and a [[Literacy in India|literacy rate]] of 88.62%. The literacy rate of Mangalore city is 94%. [[Tuluvas]], distributed among the [[Billava]], [[Mogaveera]], [[Bunt (community)|Bunt]], Koraga, Kulala, and [[Devadiga]] communities, are the largest ethnic group in the district.{{cite web |url=http://dsal.uchicago.edu/reference/gazetteer/pager.html?objectid=DS405.1.I34_V14_365.gif |title= Imperial Gazetteer of India, South Kanara|accessdate= 4 September 2009 |publisher=dsal.uchicago.edu}} The [[Konkani people|Konkani]] people, Brahmins, [[Holeya]]s, [[Vokkaliga]]s, the hill-tribes ([[Koraga people|Koragas]]), [[Muslims]], [[Mangalorean Catholics]] and [[Kodagu Gowda|Arebhashe Gowdas]] comprise rest of the population.{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-karnataka/article1874840.ece |title= Mangaluru: It has come a long way|accessdate= 23 May 2015 |publisher=The Hindu |date=18 July 2007}} The Brahmins belong chiefly to the [[Chitpavan]], [[Shivalli Brahmins|Shivalli]], [[Saraswat Brahmin|Saraswat]], [[Havyaka Brahmin|Havyaka]], and [[Kota Brahmin|Kota]] sub-sections.{{cite web| url = http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in:8080/jspui/bitstream/10603/18567/15/15_chapter%203.pdf| title = Chapter-3 Village: Land, Culture and Ecology| accessdate = 21 June 2015| publisher= Shodhganga}} The major languages spoken in Dakshina Kannada are [[Tulu language|Tulu]], [[Konkani]], [[Kannada]], [[Beary language|Beary Bhashe]] and [[Are Bhashe dialect|Are Bhashe]].{{cite web| url = http://www.caluniv.ac.in/global-mdia-journal/ARTICLES_JUNE_2013/ARTICLE-%204-Poornananda.pdf| title = Pilgrimage to Temples in Dakshina Kannada| accessdate = 22 February 2015| author= Tamarapu Sampath Kumaran}} == Geography == [[File:Western Ghats view near Kukke.jpg|thumb|right|[[Western Ghats]] near [[Kukke Subramanya]]]] [[File:Surathkal Lighthouse1.jpg|thumb|left|[[Lighthouse]] alongside [[Surathkal]] Beach]] The district geography consists of seashore in the west and [[Western Ghats]] in the east. The [[soil]] is mostly [[laterite|lateritic]] type, characterised by high [[iron]] and [[aluminium]] content.{{cite web| url = http://cgwb.gov.in/District_Profile/karnataka/DAKSHINA_KANNADA.pdf | title = Ground Water Information Booklet - Dakshina Kannada | accessdate =25 May 2015| publisher = Government of India - Ministry of Water Resources|date=November 2009}} The major rivers are [[Netravathi]], [[Kumaradhara]], [[Phalguni river|Gurupura (Phalguni)]], [[Shambhavi]], Nandini or [[Pavanje]] and Payaswini which all join the [[Arabian sea]].{{cite web| url = http://pppinindia.com/pdf/karnataka/District%20Profiles/Dakshin%20Kannada.pdf | title = Dakshina Kannada District Profile | accessdate =22 February 2015| publisher = Government of Karnataka}} At [[Uppinangadi]], the Netravathi and Kumaradhara rivers rise during the monsoon and meet, this event is called "Sangam", which in Sanskrit means confluence.{{cite web| url = http://www.deccanherald.com/content/14551/kumaradhara-nethravathi-rivers-merge-uppinangady.html | title = Kumaradhara, Nethravathi rivers merge at Uppinangady | accessdate =20 May 2015 | date=19 July 2009| publisher = Deccan Herald}} Near Mangalore, an [[estuary]] is formed by the union of the rivers Netravathi and the Gurupura which merge into the Arabian Sea.{{cite web| url = http://mbai.org.in/uploads/manuscripts/Article-7696218637.pdf | title = Ecological observations on the phytoplankton of Nethravati - Gurupura estuary, south west coast of India | accessdate =25 May 2015 | date=30 January 2009| publisher = Marine Biological Association of India|author=M S Shruthi|author2=M Rajashekhar}} The [[topography]] of the district is plain up to {{convert|30|km|mi|2|abbr=on}} inside the coast and changes to undulating hilly [[terrain]] sharply towards the east in the Western Ghats.{{cite book | title = Mausam: quarterly journal of meteorology, hydrology & geophysics, Volume 56, Issue 1 | publisher = [[India Meteorological Department]] | year = 2005 | page = 76}} [[Teak]], [[bamboo]] and rosewood trees are found in the hilly areas towards the east.{{cite web| url = http://www.arvindguptatoys.com/arvindgupta/santapau.pdf | title = Common Trees | accessdate =25 May 2015 |author = H Santapau}} The [[Geological Survey of India]] has identified this district as a moderately earthquake-prone region and categorised it in the Seismic III Zone.{{cite map |publisher=[[Geological Survey of India]] |url=http://gcmd.nasa.gov/records/GCMD_GSI_BHUJ_SEISMIC_ZONES_MAP.html|title=Seismic zoning map of India|accessdate=20 July 2008}} In rural Dakshina Kannada, houses are in the midst of a farm field or [[plantation]]s of [[coconut]] or [[arecanut]], separated by a few hundred metres.{{cite web| url = http://parisara.kar.nic.in/PDF/Forest.pdf | title = Forest - State of the Environment Report - 2003 (Page 189) | accessdate =20 May 2015 | publisher = Parisara}} {{wide image|Mangalore_panaroma_0187_pan.jpg|1100px|Mangalore skyline from Kadri}} == Education and research == [[File:NITK mangalore.jpg|thumb|right|[[NITK Surathkal]]]] [[File:St. Aloysius College.jpg|thumb|right|[[St. Aloysius College (Mangalore)|St Aloysius College]]]] In Dakshina Kannada, primary and secondary education have reached every section of the society.{{cite web |url=http://www.educareonline.in/kardist/dakshinakannada.html |title=Educare Online - Colleges in Dakshina Kannada |accessdate=7 February 2016 |publisher=Educare Online }}{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Mangalore/dakshina-kannada-pips-udupi-to-top-in-pu-performance/article5992466.ece |title=Dakshina Kannada pips Udupi to top in PU performance |accessdate=23 May 2015 |date=9 May 2014 |publisher=The Hindu }} A host of educational institutes offering courses in [[Medicine]], [[Engineering]], [[Pharmacy]], [[Nursing]], Hotel and Catering, Law and Management are located in this district.{{cite web |url=http://www.new1.dli.ernet.in/data1/upload/insa/INSA_1/20005af6_260.pdf |title=A brief history of scientific technology, research and educational progress of South Kanara |accessdate=20 May 2015 |publisher=Indian Journal of History of Science |author=M N Madhyastha |author2=M Abdul Rahman |author3=K M Kaveriappa}} Dakshina Kannada is home to the National Institute of Technology Karnataka (NITK) Surathkal, one of India's top Engineering colleges.{{cite web |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/tech/slideshow/techcolleges/Indias-10-top-engineering-colleges/itslideshowviewall/12003525.cms |title=India's 10 top Engineering colleges |accessdate=25 May 2015 |publisher=Times of India |date=23 Feb 2012}} The [[College of Fisheries]] is located at Yekkur near [[Kankanady]].{{cite news| url = http://www.kvafsu.kar.nic.in/College%20of%20Fisheries.htm | date = 31 August 2006| title = College of Fisheries, Mangaluru | accessdate = 7 September 2009| publisher=Karnataka Veterinary Animal and Fishereies University}}{{cite news| url = http://www.cofmangalore.org/ | title = College of Fisheries, Mangalore | accessdate = 20 May 2015| publisher=Karnataka Veterinary Animal and Fishereies University}} [[Mangalore University]] is a public university in [[Konaje]] near [[Mangalore]]. It has jurisdiction over the districts of Dakshina Kannada, [[Udupi district|Udupi]] and [[Kodagu district|Kodagu]].{{cite web |url= http://www.hindu.com/2004/09/08/stories/2004090811840300.htm |title=The Hindu : Karnataka / Mangalore News : Mangalore University all set to celebrate jubilee |work=hindu.com |accessdate=31 December 2011}} The district is home to research institutes such as the Directorate of Cashew Research at [[Puttur, Karnataka|Puttur]].{{cite web |url= http://www.cashew.res.in/ |title=ICAR: Directorate of Cashew Research, Puttur, Karnataka |work=DCR |accessdate=20 May 2015}} The Central Plantation Crops Research Institute is situated at [[Vitla]] in the [[Bantwal]] taluk.{{cite web |url= http://www.cpcri.gov.in/ |title=ICAR: Central Plantation Crops Research Institute |work=ICAR |accessdate=20 May 2015}} The various Engineering colleges in the district include [[St. Joseph Engineering College]], [[KVG College of Engineering]], [[Mangalore Institute of Technology & Engineering]], [[Canara Engineering College]], [[P A College of Engineering]], [[Srinivas Group of College|Srinivas Institute of Technology]], Srinivas School of Engineering, Vivekananda College of Engineering & Technology, Shree Devi Institute of Technology, Alvas Institute of Engineering & Technology, Karavali Institute of Technology, Sahyadri College of Engineering & Management, M.V.Shetty Institute of Technology, [[SDM College, Ujire|SDM Institute of Technology]], [[Bearys Institute of Technology]] and Prasanna College of Engineering & Technology.{{cite web |url= http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-karnataka/colleges-around-mangalore-join-hands-for-campus-placements/article2911958.ece |title=The Hindu : Karnataka / Mangalore News : Colleges around Mangalore join hands for Campus Placements |work=hindu.com |accessdate=14 May 2015 | publisher=The Hindu}} The various Medical colleges in the district include [[A J Institute of Medical Science]], [[Father Muller Medical College]], [[KS Hegde Medical Academy]], [[Kasturba Medical College]], [[Srinivas Institute of Medical Sciences and Research Centre]], Yenepoya Medical College & Research Institute and KVG Medical College. In 1907, the [[Southern Railway zone|Southern Railway]] connected Mangalore with [[Kozhikode|Calicut (Kozhikode)]] along the coastline.{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/railways-cross-a-milestone/article748488.ece |title=Railways cross a milestone |accessdate= 13 June 2015 |date=12 April 2010 |publisher=The Hindu}} This railway line helped connect the district with other places of the Madras presidency during the [[Colonial India|colonial rule]].{{cite web |url=http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in/bitstream/10603/12705/10/10_chapter%202.pdf|title= Chapter II: Origin and Development of Southern Railway |accessdate= 20 May 2015 |publisher=Shodhganga}} The [[Konkan Railway]] (1998) connects Dakshina Kannada with [[Maharashtra]], [[Goa]], [[Gujarat]], [[Delhi]], [[Rajasthan]] and [[Kerala]] by train.{{cite web|url= http://www.unep.org/Transport/lowcarbon/Pdf's/ImpactAssessment.pdf|title=A case study of Konkan Railways |accessdate=25 May 2015|publisher=UNEP - IIM Ahmedabad}} There are direct trains from Mangalore to Mumbai, [[Thane]], [[Chennai]], Goa and [[Trivandrum]].{{cite web|url= http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Chennai/article2387166.ece |title=Southern Railway to operate special trains|date= 23 August 2011 |accessdate=15 December 2011 |publisher=[[The Hindu]]}} Train services operate daily to Bangalore via Hassan and [[Kukke Subramanya]] after the conversion from [[metre gauge]] to [[broad gauge]] track.{{cite news| url=http://www.hindu.com/2007/11/24/stories/2007112461660400.htm| date = 24 November 2007|title = Bangalore-Mangalore train service from December 8| accessdate =2 October 2008| publisher =''[[The Hindu]]''}} The Dakshina Kannada district has a [[seaport]] at [[Panambur]]. Research Report No. 6| accessdate = 23 May 2015| publisher=ProGlo|author=Jananie Kalyanaraman|author2=Leah Koskimaki|date=January 2013}} [[Farm]]s and fields are being converted into residential plots and commercial (shopping) complexes.{{cite web| url =http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mangaluru/Agriculture-festival-to-look-at-revival-of-paddy-farming-in-Dakshina-Kannada/articleshow/45920992.cms | title = Agricultute festival to look at revival of paddy farming in Dakshina Kannada| accessdate = 25 May 2015| publisher=Times of India}} [[Horticulture]] though has made some strides, and measures have been taken to improve the fruit plantation sector.{{cite web| url =http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Mangalore/clusters-formed-in-dakshina-kannada-to-promote-fruit-plantation-crops/article4030427.ece | title = Clusters formed in Dakshina Kannada to promote fruit plantation crops| accessdate = 25 May 2015| publisher=The Hindu}} The main crops of Dakshina Kannada are [[rice|Paddy]], [[Coconut]], [[Arecanut]], [[Black Pepper]], [[Cashew]] and [[Cocoa bean|Cocoa]]. [[Rubber]], [[Banana]] and [[Vanilla]] crops are also cultivated in the Sullia taluk.{{cite web| url =http://www.isca.in/IJSS/Archive/v2i1/5.ISCA-IRJSS-2012-078.pdf | title = Contemporary Agriculture Issues from Dakshina Kannada: A Field View| accessdate = 23 May 2015| publisher=International Research Journal of Social Sciences|author=Shannikodi Ashwini|date=January 2013}} Rice is generally cultivated three seasons in a year, Karthika or Yenel (May–October), Suggi (October to January) and Kolake (January to April).{{cite news| url = http://dsal.uchicago.edu/reference/gazetteer/pager.html?objectid=DS405.1.I34_V14_368 | title = South Kanara| accessdate = 4 September 2006| publisher=Digital South Asia Library (DSAL)}} [[Urad (bean)|Urad]] or Black gram is grown in some areas during the season of Suggi.{{cite web| url =http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in:8080/jspui/bitstream/10603/25483/10/10_chapter_03.pdf | title = Chapter 3 - Profile of the study area: Coastal Karnataka | accessdate = 22 February 2015}} The [[Karnataka Milk Federation]] has a milk processing plant at [[Kulshekar]] in [[Mangalore]]. This plant processes milk procured from the [[cattle]] owned by farmers of the district.{{cite web| url =http://agricoop.nic.in/Agriculture%20contingency%20Plan/KTK/KAR13-DAKSHINA%20KANNADA%2031.03.2011.pdf | title = Agriculture Contingency Plan for District: DAKSHINA KANNADA| accessdate = 31 January
